description: Horsetail produces two differnt stalks in some species.
Common plant in the PNW, easily identifiable by its shiny, spiny, multicolored leaves. In the summer it produces a grape colored berry
Found many growing out of the moss on the side of a tree in late fall
In the honeysuckle family. White berries still on the plant into late fall
Young leaves are edible after cooking to destroy the stinging hairs
Orange leaves stuck out in the landscape. Species still needs to be identified
Introduced from Europe. The tea is used as a digestive aid, antipasmodic, laxative, expectorant and demulcent
The succulent leaves grow early in spring, often re-absorbed by the plants prior to summer flowering, such that the flowers seem to sprout directly from the dirt
Oxalic acid gives a tart, lemon-like flavor
All hawthorn berries are edible: black, blue, red or yellow
Native to western and souther Europe. A familiar Christmas decoration. evergreen
Aronia juice is available in many stores
